Title: A comparison of the efferents of the amygdala and the hippocampal formation in the rhesus monkey: I. Convergence in the entorhinal, prorhinal, and perirhinal cortices.
Abstract: This is the first in a series of papers investigating the neuroanatomical basis for the interaction of the amygdala and the hippocampal formation in the rhesus monkey. The present report focuses on the complementary and convergent projections of the amygdala and hippocampal formation to the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices. These results were obtained from complementary experiments using injections of radioactively labeled amino acids to identify the anterograde projection patterns and injections of horseradish peroxidase and fluorescent retrograde tracers to confirm the cytoarchitectonic location of the neurons of origin for each projection. The results of this investigation demonstrate that both the hippocampal formation and the amygdala project to the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices where, with a few exceptions, the major projections of each structure generally are found in different layers of the same cytoarchitecture subdivisions of the entorhinal cortex but overlap in the same layers of the perirhinal cortex. Thus, the lateral and accessory basal nuclei of the amygdala project to layer 3 of areas Pr1, 28I, 28L, and 28S, and the accessory basal nucleus projects strongly to layer 1 of these same areas. In contrast, the subiculum, prosubiculum, and subfield CA1 of the of the hippocampal formation all have a projection to layer 5 of these same areas. In area 28M, the accessory basal nucleus of the amygdala projects to layer 1, while the subiculum, prosubiculum, and subfield CA1 of the hippocampal formation all project to layer 5, and the presubiculum projects to layer 3. In addition to these complementary laminar projections, there are a few areas of laminar overlap. Thus in area 28S, both the presubiculum and the CA1 subfield project to layer 3, where the lateral and accessory basal amygdaloid nuclei also project. Similarly, in 28I there is a major projection from the presubiculum and a lighter projection from the subiculum and CA1 to layer 3, where the lateral and accessory basal nuclei also project. There is also extensive laminar overlap in the perirhinal cortex. From the amygdala, the accessory basal nucleus projects to layers 1 and 3 and the lateral basal nucleus to layers 3, 5, and 6, while from the hippocampal formation, the prosubiculum projects to layers 3, 5, and 6, and the CA1 subfield projects to layer 5. This pattern of hippocampal and amygdaloid projections to the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices indicates that these cortices constitute a region of potentially extensive interaction between the amygdala and the hippocampus.
Comments: SR88, together with SRV88, is one of a series of papers comparing the connectivity of the amygdala and the hippocampal formation.

@InterMapRelations.Comments: It is not clearly stated, from which parcellation scheme areas POC, CTA, and HATA of SR88 are adopted, but it seems that they are identical with the same areas of BR98 because (i) they approximately the same location, (ii) the same abbreviation, (iii) and D.L. Rosene is a common author of both papers.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The presubiculum (or area 27 of Brodmann, '09) lies medial to the subiculum and is a five layered periallocortex distinguishable by its characteristic lamina principalis externa and the deeper lamina principalis interna (Fig. 2, C and D). The similar but less distinct parasubiculum (area 49 of Brodmann, '09) is medially adjacent to the presubiculum and separates it from the entorhinal cortex (Fig. 2D)." (p. 160)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: It is not clearly stated, from which parcellation scheme the description of the parasubicular cortex is adopted. It is only said that it corresponds to area 49 of B09, but B09 did not show this area 49 in his map. But it is quite possible that the parasubicular cortex of SR88 is identical in its boundaries with the parasubicular cortex of BR98, because (i) they approximately the same location, (ii) the same abbreviation, (iii) and D.L. Rosene is a common author of both papers.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The presubiculum (or area 27 of Brodmann, '09) lies medial to the subiculum and is a five layered periallocortex distinguishable by its characteristic lamina principalis externa and the deeper lamina principalis interna (Fig. 2, C and D). The similar but less distinct parasubiculum (area 49 of Brodmann, '09) is medially adjacent to the presubiculum and separates it from the entorhinal cortex (Fig. 2D)." (p. 160)

"Classically, the entorhinal cortex, a periallocortex, has been divided into two main subdivisions, areas 28a and 28b (Brodmann, '09). In the monkey, the entorhinal cortex extends from the fundus of the rhinal sulcus medially and dorsally, to the cortical-amygdaloid transition area rostrally, and to the parasubiculum more caudally. In the present investigation we have identified in the primate, the five subparts of the entorhinal cortex originally described by Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75), but have modified their nomenclature to more closely parallel that used in the nonprimates and to reflect the relationships among theses areas. Thus the terms medial entorhinal (28M) and lateral entorhinal (28L) designate respectively areas 28a and 28b of Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75a). These authors further parcellated the entorhinal cortex of the monkey into three other areas. One was an intermediate cortex (28I) located between, and sharing features of, both areas 28Land 28M (Fig. 1, D; Fig. 2, A and B; Fig. 3). Van Hoesen and Pandya('75a) also identified two areas which bordered the entorhinal cortex dorsally and ventrally, and they labeled them prorhinal (Pr1) and prorhinal2, respectively. We have retained the 28I designation for the intermediate entorhinal area, since it shares features of both 28L and 28M, as well as the Pr1 designation for the rostral area bordering the olfactory cortex, since this designation accurately reflects the transitional nature of this cortex. However, while agreeing with Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75a) that the prorhinal 2 area in the superior bank of the rhinal sulcus is a unique area, we have designated it the sulcal entorhinal area (28S) to reflect the many similarities of this cortex with the rest of the entorhinal area (28L, 28I and particularly 28M)." (p. 160)

"The cortex comprising the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus has been described as transitional cortex between the entorhinal cortex and the temporal neocortex (Brodmann, '09; Van Hoesen and Pandya, '75a). This intermediate cortex has been named perirhinal cortex (Van Hoesen and Pandya, '75) or area 35 (Brodmann, '09)." (p. 162)

"The cortex comprising the lateral bank of the rhinal sulcus has been described as transitional cortex between the entorhinal cortex and the temporal neocortex (Brodmann, '09; Van Hoesen and Pandya, '75a). This intermediate cortex has been named perirhinal cortex (Van Hoesen and Pandya, '75) or area 35 (Brodmann, '09)." (p. 162)

"The description and nomenclature of the primate amygdaloid complex adopted in this investigation are derived from the original cytoarchitectural description of the human amygdala by Crosby and Humphrey ('41) and adopted from the monkey by Lauer ('45)." (p. 159)

@InterMapRelations.Comments:
Although the authors state unambiguously that they they follow the parcellation scheme of L45 for the description of the nuclei of the amygdala, they did not mention the "Intercalated cell masses" of Lauer ('45), which are described as following: "Interspersed among the nuclei of the baso-lateral amygdaloid complex are condensed plates of small nerve cells. In the macaque these occur especially along the ventral surface and above the dorsal tips of the constituent nuclei. The largest mass is found around the rostral pole of the lateral and basal nuclei, from which position it extends caudally between their dorsal tips for approximately a fourth of the total extent of the complex (figs. 7,8)." (L45, p. 223)
Either SR88 have (not) identified  these cells but did not mention their (non-) existence, or they recognized them and included them into one or more of  their illustrated nuclei, especially the lateral and lateral-/medial basal nuclei of SR88.
If the latter supposition is right, the nuclei above of SR88 do not have to be identical with the same named areas of L45, because they could also overlap with themor be a subpart of them.

"Classically, the entorhinal cortex, a periallocortex, has been divided into two main subdivisions, areas 28a and 28b (Brodmann, '09). In the monkey, the entorhinal cortex extends from the fundus of the rhinal sulcus medially and dorsally, to the cortical-amygdaloid transition area rostrally, and to the parasubiculum more caudally. In the present investigation we have identified in the primate, the five subparts of the entorhinal cortex originally described by Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75), but have modified their nomenclature to more closely parallel that used in the nonprimates and to reflect the relationships among theses areas. Thus the terms medial entorhinal (28M) and lateral entorhinal (28L) designate respectively areas 28a and 28b of Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75a). These authors further parcellated the entorhinal cortex of the monkey into three other areas. One was an intermediate cortex (28I) located between, and sharing features of, both areas 28Land 28M (Fig. 1, D; Fig. 2, A and B; Fig. 3). Van Hoesen and Pandya('75a) also identified two areas which bordered the entorhinal cortex dorsally and ventrally, and they labeled them prorhinal (Pr1) and prorhinal2, respectively. We have retained the 28I designation for the intermediate entorhinal area, since it shares features of both 28L and 28M, as well as the Pr1 designation for the rostral area bordering the olfactory cortex, since this designation accurately reflects the transitional nature of this cortex. However, while agreeing with Van Hoesen and Pandya ('75a) that the prorhinal 2 area in the superior bank of the rhinal sulcus is a unique area, we have designated it the sulcal entorhinal area (28S) to reflect the many similarities of this cortex with the rest of the entorhinal area (28L, 28I and particularly 28M)." (p. 160)

@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments:
Although the authors state unambiguously that they they follow the parcellation scheme of L45 for the description of the nuclei of the amygdala, they did not mention the "Intercalated cell masses" of Lauer ('45), which are described as following: "Interspersed among the nuclei of the baso-lateral amygdaloid complex are condensed plates of small nerve cells. In the macaque these occur especially along the ventral surface and above the dorsal tips of the constituent nuclei. The largest mass is found around the rostral pole of the lateral and basal nuclei, from which position it extends caudally between their dorsal tips for approximately a fourth of the total extent of the complex (figs. 7,8)." (L45, p. 223)
Either SR88 have (not) identified  these cells but did not mention their (non-) existence, or they recognized them and included them into one or more of  their illustrated nuclei, especially the lateral and lateral-/medial basal nuclei of SR88.
If the latter supposition is right, the nuclei above of SR88 do not have to be identical with the same named areas of L45, because they could also overlap with themor be a subpart of them.

Although the abbreviation Pr1 in SR88 stands for "prorhinal" cortex, it is seen as a subpart of the "entorhinal" cortex, because in SR88 it is said, that they divided the entorhinal coretx in five subparts, which are area 28I, L, M, S and Pr1. @Methods.Comments:
Additional to the anterograde injections into different areas of 36 animals there were retrograde injections into 6 animals in order to confirm the results of amino acid injections. They used HRP-WGA for 2 animals and three different fluorescent retrograde tracers (FRT: diamidino yellow, fast blue, and latex microspheres)  for the remaining 4 animals, but only the results of the FRT cases are presented.
"Because even the smallest amino acid injections (e.g. 7 microCi) appear to spread into at least one adjacent architectonic area of the amygdala or hippocampal formation, injections of retrograde tracers were made into the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices in six monkeys to confirm the results of the amino acid injections by identifying the architectonic location of the cellls origin of each projection pattern described above. In two monkeys, large injections of HRP-WGA were placed into the entorhinal cortex and involved all five subdivisions (Pr1, 28L, 28I, and 28S) of the entorhinal cortex as well as part of the perirhinal cortex. These cases confirmed that hippocampal projections originate from CA1, prosubiculum, subiculum, and presubiculum and that the amygdaloid projections originate primarily from the lateral and accesory basal nuclei with smaller contributions from the medial basal, medial, and cortical nuclei. To more precisely define specific contributions, more restricted FRT injections were placed into eight sites within specific subdivisions of the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices in four monkeys. Since the FRT injections provided the most precise data on the origin of the hippocampal and amygdaloid efferents, the results from these four cases are presented in figures 15, 16 and 17." (p. 174)

@Injections.Citation:
"In case E-2, the dye diamidino yellow (DY) was injected into the rostral part of 28L and spread into part of Pr1 (Fig. 15). In a second animal, case E-4, the latex microspheres (LM) were injected into the most caudal region of area 28S  (Fig. 15). The data from these two single injections cases are both presented in Fig. 15. The series of coronal sections were drawn from case E-2 where the DY labeled cells were observed, and the LM labeled cells in corresponding levels of case E-4 were plotted onto the same drawing. The other two cases had three injections each. In case E-1 (Fig. 16), one injection was restricted to the perirhinal cortex (latex microspheres, LM), and the other two were located at different rostral-caudal levels of 28M (fast blue, FB, and DY). In Case E-3 (Fig. 17) one FRT injection included both 28L and 28I (DY), while the other two injections were again in two different levels of 28M (LM and FB)." (p. 174)
"This illustration presents tracings of representative cross sections from FRT case E-1, where injections of three tracers were made into different levels of the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices. As shown in C, an injection of latex microspheres (LM) was placed into the perirhinal cortex. In the entorhinal cortex an injection of fast blue (FB) was placed in the rostral part of 28M (D), and an injection of diamidino yellow (DY) was placed in the more caudal part of 28M (E)." (p. 177, description of figure 16)

@Injections.Citation:
"There were three cases (A-6, A-19, and A-20) in which injections of radioactively labeled amino acids (7-20 microCurie) were centered in the accessory basal nucleus. In all cases there was some spread into either the adjacent lateral basal, medial, or cortical nuclei. The results of all three cases  were the same, and one (case A-6) is illustrated in Fig. 6." "This illustration presents tracings of representative cross sections of case A-6, where an injection of radioactively labeled amino acids was centered in the accessory basal nucleus but also involved the medial and cortical nuclei as well as part of the lateral basal nucleus and anterior amygdaloid area." (p. 164, description of figure 6)
"Twenty monkeys received either unilateral, or in a few cases, bilateral injections of radioactively labeled amino acids in different regions of the amygdaloid complex. Even in the cases with the smallest injections (7 micro Ci), the injection site almost always spread beyond thje boundaries of a single nucleus into one or more surrounding areas of the amygdala. However, the large number of injections (25) made it possible to identify the efferent projections of most subdivisions of the amygdala to the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices. A detailed description of these amygdaloid projections is limited to four representative cases. Results from some of the other cases will be described as needed to clarify the projections of individual nuclei." (p. 162)
@Injections.Comments: There is no direct information about the quantity of the used volume, in contrast to quantity of the radioactivity. Because the concentration of TAA (100 microCi per microliter) has been clearly mentioned, the volume of each injection can be calculated.

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation:
"Summary and comparison of amygdaloid efferents.
Injections of radioactively labeled amino acids into the amygdala reveal an extensive projection to the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices. This projection originates primarily in the lateral and the accessory basal nuclei and projects most prominently to layer 3 of 28S and 28L. Photomicrographs illustrating this are presented in Fig. 8. In addition there was consistent but slightly less dense labeling over layer 3 of areas 28I and Pr1. The lateral nucleus projection to Pr1 and 28L is organized into patches, or clusters of label, which coincide with the acellular patches of layers 2 and 3 in 28L. In contrast, the projection from the accessory basal nucleus is uniformly distributed over layer 3 and over layer1. Label was only observed in the medial entorhinal area (28M) after injections involving the accessory basal nucleus, and then was largely restricted to layer1. In the perirhinal cortex, both the accessory basal and lateral basal nuclei project lightly to layer 3, and there is also a project of layer 1 from the accessory basal nucleus, and to layers 5 and 6 from the lateral basal nucleus. While unique projections from either the cortical or the medial basal nuclei could not be identified, it is likely that they project in a pattern similar to the accessory basal and lateral basal nuclei. As described below, injections of retrogradely tracers limited to the different areas of the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices verify these observations and identify the exact site of origin within the amygdaloid complex of these projections." (p. 165)

"Eighteen monkeys received injections of retrogradely labeled amino acids in different subdivisions of the hippocampal formation or the presubiculum. In the perirhinal cortex, both the accessory basal and lateral basal nuclei project lightly to layer 3, and there is also a projection of layer 1 from the accessory basal nucleus, and to layers 5 and 6 from the lateral basal nucleus. While unique projections from either the cortical or the medial basal nuclei could not be identified, it is likely that they project in a pattern similar to the accessory basal and lateral nuclei. As described below, injections of retrograde tracers limited to the different areas of the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices verify these observations and identify the exact site of origin within the amygdaloid complex of these projections." (p. 165)
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments:
There is additional information about labeled/affected areas in the description of the corresponding figure.
Because there are only cross sections illustrated with no exact information about the distance between these cross sections, we avoided to interprete, if the labeling was partially or completely in each areas.

@Injections.Citation: "Eighteen monkeys received injections of retrogradely labeled amino acids in different subdivisions of the hippocampal formation or the presubiculum. Label in the entorhinal, prorhinal, and perirhinal cortices was observed in 12 cases where the injections involved either CA1, the prosubiculum, the subiculum, or the presubiculum. The data presented below will be limited to five representative cases from these four areas. In four cases where injections were limited to the dentate gyrus, CA4, CA3, or CA2 regions, there was no label in the prorhinal, entorhinal, or perirhinal cortices." (p. 165)
@Injections.Comments: There is no additonally detailed information in the text or in the figures about the injections into the dentate gyrus and CA2-4. Because of that even the name of the case had to be created by ourselves.

@Methods.Comments:
Additional to the anterograde injections into different areas of 36 animals there were retrograde injections into 6 animals in order to confirm the results of amino acid injections. They used HRP-WGA for 2 animals and three different fluorescent retrograde tracers (FRT: diamidino yellow, fast blue, and latex microspheres)  for the remaining 4 animals, but only the results of the FRT cases are presented.
"Because even the smallest amino acid injections (e.g. 7 microCi) appear to spread into at least one adjacent architectonic area of the amygdala or hippocampal formation, injections of retrograde tracers were made into the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices in six monkeys to confirm the results of the amino acid injections by identifying the architectonic location of the cellls origin of each projection pattern described above. In two monkeys, large injections of HRP-WGA were placed into the entorhinal cortex and involved all five subdivisions (Pr1, 28L, 28I, and 28S) of the entorhinal cortex as well as part of the perirhinal cortex. These cases confirmed that hippocampal projections originate from CA1, prosubiculum, subiculum, and presubiculum and that the amygdaloid projections originate primarily from the lateral and accesory basal nuclei with smaller contributions from the medial basal, medial, and cortical nuclei. To more precisely define specific contributions, more restricted FRT injections were placed into eight sites within specific subdivisions of the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices in four monkeys. Since the FRT injections provided the most precise data on the origin of the hippocampal and amygdaloid efferents, the results from these four cases are presented in figures 15, 16 and 17." (p. 174)

publication.title: A comparison of the efferents of the amygdala and the hippocampal formation in the rhesus monkey: I. Convergence in the entorhinal, prorhinal, and perirhinal cortices.
publication.abstract: This is the first in a series of papers investigating the neuroanatomical basis for the interaction of the amygdala and the hippocampal formation in the rhesus monkey. The present report focuses on the complementary and convergent projections of the amygdala and hippocampal formation to the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices. These results were obtained from complementary experiments using injections of radioactively labeled amino acids to identify the anterograde projection patterns and injections of horseradish peroxidase and fluorescent retrograde tracers to confirm the cytoarchitectonic location of the neurons of origin for each projection. The results of this investigation demonstrate that both the hippocampal formation and the amygdala project to the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices where, with a few exceptions, the major projections of each structure generally are found in different layers of the same cytoarchitecture subdivisions of the entorhinal cortex but overlap in the same layers of the perirhinal cortex. Thus, the lateral and accessory basal nuclei of the amygdala project to layer 3 of areas Pr1, 28I, 28L, and 28S, and the accessory basal nucleus projects strongly to layer 1 of these same areas. In contrast, the subiculum, prosubiculum, and subfield CA1 of the of the hippocampal formation all have a projection to layer 5 of these same areas. In area 28M, the accessory basal nucleus of the amygdala projects to layer 1, while the subiculum, prosubiculum, and subfield CA1 of the hippocampal formation all project to layer 5, and the presubiculum projects to layer 3. In addition to these complementary laminar projections, there are a few areas of laminar overlap. Thus in area 28S, both the presubiculum and the CA1 subfield project to layer 3, where the lateral and accessory basal amygdaloid nuclei also project. Similarly, in 28I there is a major projection from the presubiculum and a lighter projection from the subiculum and CA1 to layer 3, where the lateral and accessory basal nuclei also project. There is also extensive laminar overlap in the perirhinal cortex. From the amygdala, the accessory basal nucleus projects to layers 1 and 3 and the lateral basal nucleus to layers 3, 5, and 6, while from the hippocampal formation, the prosubiculum projects to layers 3, 5, and 6, and the CA1 subfield projects to layer 5. This pattern of hippocampal and amygdaloid projections to the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices indicates that these cortices constitute a region of potentially extensive interaction between the amygdala and the hippocampus.
